pros: 1. Culture: Extremely collegial, very little politics and the political people get weeded out (much more so than half a dozen other Fortune 500s for whom I’ve worked) 2. International: Substantial international exposure opportunities to work with, or live in 3. Employee Development: Invest significantly in employees (e.g., Stanford program) 4. Pay: Decent salary (though not on high side in Silicon Valley, stock units should be higher Valley) 5. Career Path Opportunity Coming: Big opportunity coming to rise ranks given heavy generational weighting towards Boomers and a huge gap in Gen X’ers to manage the company when the Boomers retire (although they all seem to be hanging on longer than expected) 6. Management Team: I was almost always impressed by the calm, intelligent, non-arrogant nature of the Executives...the jerks got weeded out pretty quickly
cons: 1. Title Deflation: many people are doing the work of one level above their title given how many business units under business units there are across company 2. Limited Career Path in Short Term (for Gen X’ers): until the top heavy Boomers really start leaving, but then there will be a huge vacuum of talent missing 3. Mgmt. by Committee: Occasional downside of collegial culture, too many meetings to make decisions by committee 4. Late Cycle Industries/No Growth: Print is the money maker and it’s on a secular decline that 3D printing can’t make up for quick enough, and PCs can’t cover from a margin POV...it’s gonna take time to ever become a growth company again

title: "You’ll be just another cog in the gargantuan HP machine"
pros: 1. People. Coworkers were almost always great. 2. Flexibility of work schedule. WFH and flexibility in working hours was great. 3. Pay. I’ve yet to get a job that pays me even 64% if what I made at HP. 4. Benefits Package. (PTO + insurance + retirement) 5. Company-provided equipment. (Laptops, monitors, etc) 6. Empathy and compassion from management (depending upon your individual manager) if something tragic or traumatic happens. After the death of a parent, my boss let me take four weeks of paid bereavement leave that didn’t come out of my PTO balance.
cons: 1. The culture created by management. You’re just a cog in the gargantuan HP machine. HP cares not about your hopes and dreams or your career advancement. Even if you push hard for something like mentorship, which is something they promote, your requests will likely be ignored or pushed aside. 2. Adherence to the bottom line creates job instability for employees. Sudden and unexpected layoff occur. I was “let go” and given fake reasons why. What it came down to was that I was laid off without HP calling it a lay-off so they didn’t have to report it, which would have been detrimental to the stock price. 3. If you get laid off or let go, you won’t see it coming. I had a one-on-one scheduled with my manager. As we were walking to find a conference room, we chatted like it was any other day. Just chitchat. Then we walked into a conference room in a different building and he immediately hit me with the news I was being let go. When I questioned why, he gave me a made up reason related to my performance. When I challenged him and told me he was incorrect, he fumbled over his words and gave me a different reason that was equally made up. 4. Lack of interaction with management. In the nearly five years I worked at HP, I can probably count on two hands the number of times I had real interaction (something beyond chitchat) with the two different managers for whom I worked. 5. Also, if you accept a severance package, as I did, you will never be eligible for rehire. EVER. After working for HP for 4 years and just shy of 11 months, my severance package was a half a month’s pay, but no one ever told me I’d never be able to come back and my severance paperwork never indicated as much, either. 6. Favoritism. This is definitely a problem. My first manager took the words of another person I worked with as the God’s honest truth when that person blamed me for a mistake she made. My manager never even asked me if I knew anything about the problem created by this other person. She just automatically assumed the problem arose because of me. I was told “you set us back weeks” after this other person mucked up some data she was analyzing for a new metric. This other person had asked me to look at the data and run a test, which I did exactly as she asked me to. I ran the test on literally 100 rows out of 100,000 rows for approximately 15 minutes and didn’t save anything. My second manager played favorites and I felt as if I had been “left behind” (for lack of a better term) while the other new hires I worked with were brought along much more quickly than I was. The other two new people on the team were given special treatment and paid special attention that I wasn’t. It helped if you were an athlete of some kind or if you liked mountain biking. That helped you “fit in” with the little clique created by my manager. Apparently I didn’t “fit in” because I didn’t join them on their mountain biking trek or their whitewater rafting trip one summer.

When the word comes down from on high to cut your TCOWs you have to do so regardless of how good the people are that are working for you. As you read the reviews you will notice a very different set of reviews depending which country the review is from. Management creates quite a bit of PR about how they value talent within HP, but the lack of training and/or apprenticeship opportunities to develop people into new or changing roles is almost non-existent. title: "Great company while you are needed. Outsourcing is a problem."
pros: Large, stable company with good benefits. Volunteer programs / Classes / Employee events Flexible work environments
cons: HP has shown an increasing inclination towards outsourcing work to 3rd party houses or their China campus. Many jobs are being sent overseas while qualified Americans are being caught up in "workforce reductions". There is no stability in HP. In the 10 years I was there I went through multiple restructures and mass layoffs. HP has a tendency to alternate between contracted labor and permanent employees with layoffs in between. If you are contract, be aware there is a forced 3 week unpaid shutdown during Christmas. If you are perm, be aware that if you are caught up in one of HP's workforce reductions, there is a strict no-rehire policy. In my case, HP just purchased a new campus in Spring TX and was preparing to move to the new building. We were all assigned desks and I actually bought a house and moved my family closer to the new campus. Two weeks before the building move a large group of us were "reduced". We had all been given excellent reviews, the budget seemed fine, and the reason given was a need to "refresh the talent pool". We were given a severance package and 60 days (during a forced holiday shutdown) to find a job within the company. Since most of us were unable to obtain new positions that quickly especially during a forced shutdown, we are no longer able to work at HP either as contractors or permanent employees with no timeline restrictions. Take caution if moving your family!

title: "Positive and collegial employer"

title: "Amazing company to work for"

title: "The HP Way"

title: "Great Company"

title: "An amazing place to grow, learn new things, make a difference in the world, and help create the future."

title: "IT Engineer"

title: "HP Corvallis-Engineering Position in HP Print"

Each division may be different, but those that I have the pleasure of working with are great. I have never had an issue or concern about theft, passive aggressive attitudes, falsification of reports, or anything like that. Also, there is a great work-life balance. The value on having a life, family, or fun is great. Flexibility to swap a weekday for a weekend is much appreciated. Dion does a good job at the highest level of explaining the goals for each quarter, the vision of the future, and relating worldwide accomplishments.
cons: There is doublespeak about efficiency and quality. It is hard to merge the two ideas together. The timelines for products feel rushed and there is often poor communication between different divisions/departments.

title: "Great company to work to develop your career"
pros: Positive work environment and amazing culture. The coworkers are helpful and encouraging. The problems are challenging and you get to work with very smart people. The work life balance is valued.
cons: The compensation is not as great compare to other tech company.

title: "Getting better every day! Great culture."
pros: Large company with an entrepreneurial spirit - definitely a different vibe now after the split from Hewlett-Packard, more hip and more fun. Lots of encouragement to learn and grow - you're encouraged to venture into the unknown, test new ideas and bring them to life. Co-workers tend to be very bright, supportive, and willing to share their knowledge and expertise. Opportunities to be part of global projects are many - getting to work and know people across the world has been a wonderful experience for me. Flexible work environment is a huge plus.
cons: Very fast-pace, lots to get done. Often feels like there's just never enough time.

title: "Strong company but needs to open up more opportunities for growth"
pros: Laid-back environment, flexible work hours, respectful people, plenty of work to keep you busy, lots of fun events happening all the time
cons: No set career path for non-engineers

title: "Some employees stay here forever!"
pros: HP has a culture of longer term employees. Recently they have been hiring more college grads. As for benefits, vacation time off is great! Most cases we have a flexible work schedule. I currently have a great manager. The people you work for make the difference for working here.
cons: Low increases for annual reviews.

title: "I love "the new" HP!"
pros: High morale, company is definitely moving in the right direction. Very cool things going on inside the company. Awesome CEO!
cons: No cons to share currently.

title: "Great place to innovate and grow a career"
pros: Collaborative, growth mindset culture. Lots of creativity and trying new things. Great place to grow a career, too, and a strong long-term strategy. Strong development opportunities.
cons: High growth culture so lots do to!

title: "Great company culture."
pros: The culture at HP is by far the best part of working here. People are very friendly and collaborative, and the organization is flat and egalitarian. "Cut throat" isn't in our vocabulary, and people exhibiting that style don't seem to last here. It's also nice to work for a company that truly values diversity and not just because it's an industry trend. HP also provides a lot of benefits and services to their employees, including free on-site health screenings during the work day. The local sites also hold a ton of social and fun events throughout the year.
cons: HP pays at the median for the industry, and the pathways for salary advancement are unclear. So, while the work is engaging and the benefits are good, many employees are lured away to other tech companies that pay better. HP is a pretty lean organization, which introduces the side effect of not being able to move up the leadership ladder easily. I don't know that I'll have the career advancement opportunities I'm looking for unless the right person leaves.

title: "HP way now is alive"
pros: HP has a fun atmosphere at work, it is very team oriented with everyone working towards a common goal. There is the opportunity to work on great projects with tangible results, and learn every aspect of the product development life cycle. HP offers a good benefit package, flexibility on work location and possibilities for growth within the company. Furthermore, opportunities to try different roles within HP exist via job rotations.
cons: Employees need to be self starters, there is training and mentoring, but a lot of the training is on-line and the onus to learn and grow is on the employee. This is not necessarily a down-side, but this company is not for those, who are not self-motivated. The work is done in very open/modern environments, which foster collaboration, but because of this there is not a lot of privacy. Again, not necessarily a downside, just something to consider.

title: "Great Innovative, Forward-Thinking Company"
pros: HP Inc. values and implements its empoyees' good ideas quickly.
cons: Compensation rates are not the best in class.

title: "HP Inc. Company Review"
pros: Working at HP has been an amazing experience! I have been here for a little over a year now, and have held 2 role, advancing into my second role 5 months ago. I came into HP after working at another company for the past 3 years that treated their employees terribly, especially the women. Since coming to HP my entire life has changed. I am so grateful that I can say I wake up every morning and am excited to come in to work. HP represents everything I believe in - diversity, family/work balance, flexible hours, positive work atmosphere, great leadership/management, and employee engagement activities/events with all employees on site. HP is a breath of fresh air for me compared to where I was at. I am very excited and looking forward to where the rest of my career within HP will take me. due to the positivity I am surrounded by on a daily basis in the office. I have a wonderful relationship with my current manager, and my original manager, I am involved in a Business Impact Network on site allowing me to meet employees from all over the company,
cons: Great company. No cons as of now for me.

title: "the New HP is a great place to be!"

title: "Great place for high performers to gain experience in many different areas"

If you are confident, perform well and seek out new challenges, HP Inc brings amazing career opportunities. I have been paid well and Managers get a generous bonus (based on company performance)
cons: Pockets of HP can have a lot of politics, where it is more important to make sure people are happy than to get your job done. Most of the managers I have had have been poor at giving constructive feedback on growth opportunities for my career.

title: "Best place I've ever worked"

They don't seem easily threatened by different perspectives. This makes for a very innovative environment, where we're constantly learning and growing together.
cons: We're still building our new company, so some things aren't as established as in other large companies. For example, our campuses are a bit "hack". (But that also leaves room for us to make our mark and have input.)

title: "I love HP, here's why"

Sacred cow no longer producing milk? Challenge it.
cons: Productivity (IT) can be a challenge sometimes, but they are trying...hey, you try splitting a Fortune 10 company in half and see what happens!

title: "Excellent environment to expand your skills and abilities, enabling you to exceed your career goals."

title: "Software Engineer"
pros: Working along some very sharp people. For the most part there is a strong sense of commitment and teamwork. Also, for the motivated, there are opportunities to do different things and in fact management encourages moving around between various job disciplines. Since the takeover by Dion, the commitment to making very friendly and exciting products has escalated.
cons: Strategy to drive all work possible to offshore locations. Unfortunately, this increases the stress to onshore people who have to mentor and train the offshore labor. It is very hard to take ownership for an extremely interesting project without it being fractured across timezones. The result is a very exhausting schedule between daytime and nighttime meetings. It is not uncommon to have a 14 hour start to finish day (with gaps in the middle). The office environment is subpar compared to the competition. People are packed 4/quad and there is absolutely no privacy and ability to focus on work without using noise cancelling headphones. Fortunately, there is some flexibility to work from home which can give you a better focus environment.

title: "Good benefits"
pros: Good amount of time off. Pretty decent and many healthcare options.
cons: Politics and egos can be frustrating.

title: "A good place to start"
pros: Work life balance is good. Most the time you can get away with 35 - 45 hours a week. People are generally good and friendly. There is no yelling and throwing at people. Benefits are good: 17 Days a vacation starting out is nice. 4% 401K match, Tuition reimbursement program, College debut assistance, 4 hours of volunteering a month. We have lots of clubs at the Vancouver site. We have four person pods instead of grey cubes. There is plenty of decorations and self expression around. Tools and processes are getting improved. 5% discount on stock purchase. A lot of people here are life long employees with 20 years plus at HP. Parents and their kids work here, and people even marry coworkers!
cons: Pay is low and promotions are hard to come by. You will get small 2% raise every-other year and bonus. It all depends on company performance, and how much funds your team is given. If you are in a good performing team and your manager is given money then you will have no problem getting a 4% raise each year, but it is really all out of your control. Ineffective and incompetent people are not fired. There are a fair amount of lazy people that are just coasting here. That said there are some bright people here but they are few and far between. Upper management is incompetent and comes up with stupid project ideas that you have to implement against your better judgment. We used to have various year round celebrations but management cut those back. There is really no career growth potential unless you want to grind out 10 years. Once you pass entry and intermediate you land into the career plateau knows as specialist. It will take five years to get to the next career ranking, unless you leave and come back like so many do. On top of that, every 18 months or so is a company re-organization, which sometimes includes jobs going over seas.

They were also not 100% PCI compliant while I was working there, to the point they were using sticky notes and giving customer info to somebody over the phone who was also keeping the info on paper in their unsecured home in Mexico.

title: "Prepare to lose your family"
pros: Fair pay, not high or low. Functions at the facilities, mainly put on and organized by employees, but the company does add some to it. Can sometimes work from home, but this is largely used to get 12-16 hours a day and weekends out of people.
cons: The running joke at HPI among thousands of employees is, "The work / life balance is that work is your life now. That's the balance". Prepare for required overtime, required working on Veterans Day (even if on a Saturday or Sunday), required working every single day straight for 19 days in November including Saturdays and Sundays in many departments (although not all). It's not a one time event, they actually plan to do this every single year. If you do not work overtime, you cannot keep up with workloads as they purposely plan to give more work than employees can do in 40 hours. Required working through vacations! Even on vacation, most positions it's required to check and respond to emails, even do file work for your position. I have never once had a real vacation off and a couple of them turned into regular 12 hour working days that I never even got to see my family except at dinner. Very strong political views. During the election I received more emails from executives about how evil and awful one side was than I did about HPI. It was depressing that I had to be bombarded at work constantly.

title: "Bloated, and slipshod with aquisitions"
pros: Good benefits and company discounts. We were acquired, so hard to distinguish between our companies benefits vs HP, although they did not change in any negative way. The Sunnyvale, Moffett location has an AMAZING gym. The company is so large, there are many opportunities for growth and experiences.
cons: We had an outstanding company that was acquired by HP. We watched sales actually go down with their bloated and bureaucratic style of doing business. To be fair, we were a mid-sized, scrappy company, so some reduction in speed would be expected. But we also saw a lot of needless delay and disinterest in the things that our company got right. Don't buy small, profitable companies if you don't know what do do with them... My sentiment has been confirmed recently, as this company was sold off from HP several months ago. We all benefited from the sale, but it's sad to see that HP had no idea with what to do with the exceptional technology and model our company had created.

Complicating the picture is that in the U.S. and Europe HP has an aging workforce and has efforts in place to shift to a younger demographic. title: "HP in steady state of decline"
pros: HP's working culture has always been inviting and collaborative. Staff is friendly and not cut throat as I have seen in other companies. After a time of stagnating innovation, HP is moving hard toward developing more innovative products. New blood in management is bringing fresh ideas into a older company. * Career opportunities are stagnating but HP does do a good job of promoting from within. * Benefits are slightly above average but have tended to get more restrictive over time. * HP pays generous signing bonuses for new employees.
cons: HP has in recent years fallen off as an employer of choice In my opinion. First the business has suffered greatly in the marketplace as the sale of its products and its market share has declined. This has led to a great deal of turnover and volatility in the business. Hiring at HP has been slowed to frozen at times and in my own experience my staff was never back-filled when someone left. When I came to HP I was being considered for promotion. Now, after several years, the company has split, my staff divided and gone, and now I am no longer even a manager much less promoted. Career? Dead end at HP! Other Cons include: * HP's remote worker policy that HP was known for has all but been eliminated. * Salary increases hover around 1-2% YoY even for top performers. * In my best year, 2 months after receiving a productivity award, I received a 1.1% raise. * Bonuses: With my staff eliminated after HP split, my bonuses on avg will fall from >$10K to ~$5K if lucky.. * Work/family balance is still decent at HP, but has declined in the last 2 years. * Some staff resistant to obstinate about collaboration and working together in EMEA. I cannot recommend HP as a place to work right now (2016) because of the volatility. Too many workforce reductions in recent months and years and the threat of more loom in the near future make a recommendation untenable.

title: "Stagnant and Sisyphean career."

cons: -You get looked down on for being a younger employee, company is primarily baby boomers an the culture is very resistant to change (the number of older employees that gripe for "the Compaq Days" is nuts). Could be my organization that's the issue here, but I've had coworkers in other groups tell me similar stories. -Company claims about quality are poorly demonstrated when known mistakes are repeated over and over again i.e. having ODM's take on the bulk of design work, significant resistance to changes that would make a product more robust, etc. -Many solutions to address employee gripes or concerns are very convoluted and I feel miss the point. There was a lot of noise about a lack of career development so we launched a social learning platform that requires employees to do all the work teaching others without additional incentives... what? Wouldn't it had just been simpler to get a new learning tool like Lynda or something other than the crappy one we had? -Raises and bonuses are based on a "trickle down" mentality, essentially if your team outshines everyone else in the company but the organization as a whole screws up, you get nothing or punished for it. The team I was on supported multiple sides and teams in the company but the fact that my parent organization didn't do well meant that I didn't reap any of the benefits. -It's easy to get caught in the wave of work that comes in and feel like a workhorse doing the same thing on a day to day basis. The spark that came with the new challenges and research is pretty much gone now and I feel that it might be time to find a new career.

title: "HP Barcelona: The perfect place for low-average professionals who are family / friend of..."
pros: - If you don't want to work too much, it's perfect as once's your in no one will fire you. As they say "It doesn't look good to fire" - Amazing benefits and facilities - It's a big company with nearly unlimited resources - You can live good life - If you're in Marketing (and not a contractor) you'll be good (technical positions are low valued)
cons: - When one of my colleagues got an offer from another company and talked with his manager at HP he literally told him "HP is not a place for XX people like you". - HP way. It looks amazing from the outside but when you dig in a little bit you see the true meaning of those words: if you need to destroy someone's career or reputation or become friends with... in order to get promoted, then do it. - Socialization matters more than good job. - If a colleague is not working and delays a project, you'd better not ask your manager to encourage him to work better as you will get bad reputation for it and probably won't get your bonus. - If a manager is not doing a good job and all this team leaves the team (it has been a real situation), he is seen as a hero and gets promoted. - Technical people that don't do their job, get promoted to managers. - Most manager don't know how to manage people. - Really tight deadlines for project development so they prioritize time over quality. - If there are two candidates applying for the same position and one is family of friend of, even if the other candidate is the perfect person for the position it will not be hired. - There are entire families working on the same departments. - Too many managers: there are more managers than technical staff and even what they call 'people managers' without 'people' - Too many people that leave their work to 'their' contractors, do nothing and get awarded for it. - Too many managers and 'colleagues' unscrupulous who don't mind step over you to be promoted. - After asking for the action the company does to keep good professionals, I was told there was nothing of the sort. - After someone from HP international went to the offices in late 2017, engineers' salary was increased by 30% as is was way under salary range.
